body:
This is happening consistently in master https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master_macos/

See builds 2343-2350

Also  saw these failing:
```
c++_macos_dbg_native.bins/dbg/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.SimpleBidiStreamingWithCoalescingApiWL/87
c++_macos_dbg_native.bins/dbg/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.SimpleClientStreamingWithCoalescingApi/49
```
https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_pull_requests_macos/5367/#showFailuresLink
I'm not familiar with these tests. Reassigning
Seen again in master in builds 2351-2391

seen again:
https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_pull_requests_macos/5398/#showFailuresLink

```
c++_macos_dbg_native.bins/dbg/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.ServerCheckCancellation/66
c++_macos_dbg_native.bins/dbg/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.SimpleBidiStreaming/71
c++_macos_dbg_native.bins/dbg/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.SimpleServerStreamingWithCoalescingApiWL/49
c++_macos_opt_native.bins/opt/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc/52
c++_macos_opt_native.bins/opt/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.SimpleRpc/51
```

Still failing in master
https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master_macos/2409/

Seen in all gRPC_master_macos builds [2554](https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master_macos/2554/#showFailuresLink) through [2581](https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master_macos/2581/#showFailuresLink).
Not seen in a while, closing.

Seen again in 
https://sponge.corp.google.com/target?id=651e3fac-b7ef-4ccc-a44a-dfcab0895662&target=github/grpc/c%2B%2B_macos_dbg_native&searchFor=&show=FAILED&sortBy=STATUS
https://sponge.corp.google.com/target?id=e480f350-575a-4b0c-bd0c-f7c939fb655e&target=github/grpc/c%2B%2B_macos_opt_native&searchFor=&show=FAILED&sortBy=STATUS

I see three occurrence:
```
bins/dbg/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc/17 GRPC_POLL_STRATEGY=poll


bins/opt/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc/18 GRPC_POLL_STRATEGY=poll
bins/opt/async_end2end_test --gtest_filter=AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc/17 GRPC_POLL_STRATEGY=poll
```

The log is like

This only seems to be happening for  UnimplementedRpc test now.

Recent failures:
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=e4a158f4-b3a0-4cee-acb0-5aadee5dd0c0
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=6fb60be8-f1de-4a28-86cb-90dffb91f92d

https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=d869cd62-f4b2-4853-bb87-8a752a5f2458

The key message is here: `async_end2end_test(98597,0x700000187000) malloc: *** error for object 0x7f829a80df30: double free
*** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug`

Other failures say this:
```
D0124 08:42:42.397141000 140735258615808 dns_resolver.cc:294]          Using native dns resolver

E0124 08:42:42.437055000 140735258615808 connectivity_state.cc:186]    assertion failed: cur != GRPC_CHANNEL_SHUTDOWN
```
@AspirinSJL   it looks like this has to do with subchannel statuses and connectivity - do you wanna take a look?

The double-free log is begging for a run under asan. Unfortunately I can't take a look as I don't have a mac, but definitely asan is the way to go. 
In the second case, something is trying to transition a subchannel out of SHUTDOWN, which is illegal. A gdb coredump and a "bt" would indicate who.
Looking.

I just pulled master to my mac and ran `tools/run_tests/run_tests.py -l c++ -r "AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc" -n inf -S -c dbg`. It has passed 23000+ runs without any failure.

@jtattermusch Any suggestion about reproducing it?

I'd suggest using antagonist, about 4 or 6 for a laptop.

On Thu, 1 Feb 2018, 12:41 Juanli Shen, <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I just pulled master to my mac and ran tools/run_tests/run_tests.py -l
> c++ -r "AsyncEnd2end/AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc" -n inf -S -c dbg.
> It has passed 23000+ runs without any failure.
>
> @jtattermusch <https://github.com/jtattermusch> Any suggestion about
> reproducing it?
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you modified the open/close state.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/11116#issuecomment-362395102>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAHVmdAIO9LAES7GqAOzSvpXLmuoIaBVks5tQiFygaJpZM4NZWdG>
> .
>
Burned some CPU cycles for 10000+ runs with `-a 6` and 27000+ runs with `-a 10`; still can't reproduce.
I will check the double-free bug instead.

Actually, I also had trouble reproducing locally (so far no luck). I don't have idea except:
- Sometimes, a flake only shows up if other tests are running in parallel (while when trying to reproduce, you usually only run a single specific test). That of course makes things harder to reproduce, as you spend most of the CPU time running other tests and not the one you are interested it.
- Another option is to do some educated guesswork and try to artificially slow down specific parts of the test to make the flake more likely.
- It also might be more likely to happen on the kokoro mac machines - we have the ability to run experiments there, but it's definitely more time consuming than reproducing locally and you can't really iterate quickly with that approach, so I'd only try this as the last resort.
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=c4be75e2-1774-4249-947b-c11d9c1940b9

Hmm.. I still can't reproduce it locally on my mac, for neither bug. The only issue I see is that it times out for once. 

How frequent are those failures?

Not very frequent: once every 40 builds perhaps?

you can use this bigquery to find out yourself:
```
select * from jenkins_test_results.aggregate_results where
  job_name like '%'
  and test_name like '%AsyncEnd2endTest.UnimplementedRpc%'
  and timestamp > '2017-10-25 00:00'
  and result != 'PASSED'
order by timestamp desc
limit 1000
```
But considering the error message is almost always the same, there's definitely something wrong with either our code or test.

Not seen since 2018-03-14; closing for now. 

BTW, this is one of the LB tests that are unreproducible locally.
